content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 ensure that group health plans provide equal coverage for mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements that are not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. This section does not prohibit separate reimbursement rates or service delivery systems for different benefits, or the use of mechanisms to manage benefit provision. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 allow for separate reimbursement rates and service delivery systems for different benefits, and the use of mechanisms to manage benefit provision. It does not require specific mental health benefits or prevent the application of subsection (a) without regard to benefits for preventive care. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. This section amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to apply the same limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits as mental health benefits. The provisions of section 712 apply to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits in the same way as mental health benefits.
